text: now an australian icon the koala has
been classed as endangered the number of
koalas has fallen sharply along much of
the east coast due to land clearing
bushfires and disease scientists say
that the population in the state of new
south wales has decreased by up to 60
percent in the last 11 years now dr
kelly lee is the executive director of
the non-profit research body science for
wildlife and i asked her what was behind
the rapid decline in numbers during the
last decade
it's a pretty grim day to see the
endangered listing today um it's been a
combination of threats so habitat loss
is definitely the key driver that we've
seen they certainly prefer really good
soil types but there's also chlamydial
disease that's really been heavily
impacting the populations um and
certainly the black summer fires that we
saw two years ago had a devastating
impact across most of the eastern states
let's take that that first reason that
you gave loss of habitats i wonder about
where that leads the recovery effort for
this species i mean how do you get to
increase the population and take species
often endangered lift if they've got
nowhere to live
yeah absolutely and and that is a big
challenge in a lot of areas the koalas
do prefer
habitats that are on good soil types
that people also prefer for development
and agriculture so there has been a big
net loss of habitat over the last couple
of decades and it's been accelerating
pretty much every year
under the increased protections now
under the epbc act the hope is that that
you know the decisions are much more in
the favor of the koalas and that the
habitat loss is stemmed we've also been
finding them in inside protected areas
which has been quite hopeful but then
under climate change that's now an added
challenge as well
now a new south wales inquiry suggested
that koalas could become extinct by 2050
what needs to be done to prevent that
from
happening look at a lot needs to be done
to be honest and we really have to
manage them across land tenures so we do
some of the work we're doing here in the
blue mountains is looking at potential
climate refugia and also now fire
refugia and we're trying to work out how
to manage koalas under increasingly
intense and frequent bush fires
so you need to look
at the
the thresholds inside the protected
areas which also includes disease but
also to stem that habitat loss you know
we've got to stop sometime soon and we
now need to do it um while we've got
some koalas left you know now that
they're endangered it's no longer enough
for us to just try and hang on to what
we've got left we need to actively
increase population numbers and that
means increasing koala habitat as well
how hopeful are you that things can be
turned around
i think
you know if there's any animal that we
can save that will turn things around
it's our iconic koala there's certainly
particularly since the fires been a
really high level of community concern
and also political will is increasing
um in order to try and conserve them in
new south wales you know there's been a
statement by the new south wales
government that they want to double
koala numbers by 2050 and really reverse
the trend
so it's now a wait and see game to see
how that changes and is implemented on
the grounds because it is a
big ask
um there's certainly a lot of tree
planting and various things going on but
obviously the the key thing right now to
hang on to the coils that we have is to

um and to stop any net losses
